Alan, I looked at your website References for one referring to the increased risk of Cancer and Parkinson's, but none of the titles seemed to reference those diseases. Can you give me a Reference that supports your claim of increased "Risks" with low LDL?

‎08-11-2011 01:41 AM

I'll reply with two posts, this one for Parkinsons and the next for cancer.

If you look at Cholesterol, Fats, Carbs, Statins and Exercise you will see underlying links here:

11. Low LDL is also dangerous and can be related to other problems such as Parkinson's Disease, cancer and other causes of early death.

The Parkinson's paper is:

Mov Disord. 2008 May 15;23(7):1013-8.
Low LDL cholesterol and increased risk of Parkinson's disease: prospective results from Honolulu-Asia Aging Study.
Huang X, Abbott RD, Petrovitch H, Mailman RB, Ross GW.
Source

Department of Neurology, University of North Carolina School of Medicine, Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27599-7025, USA. xuemei@med.unc.edu

Abstract

Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) levels are suggested to be associated inversely with Parkinson's disease (PD).

To test the hypothesis that LDL-C levels may increase PD risk, we studied a prospective cohort of 3,233 men (Honolulu-Asia Aging Study) for whom the LDL-C from fasting lipid profiles was obtained during 1991 to 1993. The cohort was followed longitudinally until 2001 for incident Parkinson's cases.

During follow-up, 41 men developed PD (18.4/10,000 person-years). Although the incidence of PD increased with decreasing LDL-C in a dose-dependent manner, the association was only significant for men aged 71 to 75 years. In the latter group, risk of PD declined from 38.5/10,000 person-years in men with LDL-C levels <80 mg/dl to less than 9/10,000 person-years for concentrations that were > or =140 mg/dl. After adjustment for age, smoking, coffee intake, and other factors, the relative odds of PD for men at the 80th versus the 20th percentile of LDL-C (135 vs. 85 mg/dl) was 0.4 (95% confidence interval: 0.2, 0.9).

This prospective study supports the hypothesis that low LDL-C is associated with an increased risk of PD. Although confirmation is required, the underlying mechanisms may be useful in understanding key aspects of PD.

My only editing was to break that into paragraphs for clarity. The paper suggests further study. I haven't looked lately so I'll try to find if there are any further related studies. But that is certainly enough to cause me, as a person not too far from my 70s, to question the value of artificially depressing my LDL levels.
Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.

‎08-11-2011 01:56 AM

Here is the abstract on Cancer, my link goes to the full text pdf:

Independent associations between low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and cancer among patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus

Xilin Yang PhD, WingYee So MBChB, Gary T.C. Ko MD, Ronald C.W. Ma MBChB, Alice P.S. Kong MBChB, Chun-Chung Chow MBBS, Peter C.Y. Tong PhD, Juliana C.N. Chan MD

Abstract

Background: The risk association between low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and cancer remains controversial and largely unexplored for people not receiving statin therapy.

Methods: We examined the risk association between LDL cholesterol and cancer among patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus who were free of cancer at enrolment and whose statin use was known. We considered a variety of nonlinear relationships in our analysis.

Results: During a median follow-up period of 4.90 years, cancer developed in 270 (4.4%) of 6107 patients. Among the 3800 patients who did not receive statin therapy, the risk association between LDL cholesterol and cancer was represented by a V-shaped curve. Compared with patients whose LDL cholesterol was at least 2.80 mmol/L (108 ) but less than 3.80 mmol/L (147 mg/dL), the risk of cancer, death from any cause or the composite outcome of cancer or death was greater among those with an LDL cholesterol level of less than 2.80 mmol/L (108 mg/dL) (hazard ratio for cancer 1.74, 95% confidence interval 1.20–2.52) and those with an LDL cholesterol level of 3.80 mmol/L (147 mg/dL) or greater (hazard ratio for cancer 1.87, 95% CI 1.29–2.71). Using 3.8 mmol/L (147 mg/dL) as a reference point, we found that the hazard ratio for cancer for every millimole per litre absolute change in LDL cholesterol was 1.54 (95% CI 1.19–1.99) among patients not using statins; the hazard ratio was reduced to 1.24 (1.01–1.53) for the entire sample (statin users and those not using statins).

These associations persisted after adjustment for covariates and exclusion of patients with less than 2.5 years of follow-up.

Interpretation: Among patients with type 2 diabetes, the association between LDL cholesterol and cancer was Vshaped, whereby both low and high levels of LDL cholesterol were associated with elevated risk of cancer.

My only editing is to add conversions to US mg/dl numbers for you.

I'll comment on the implications in my next message.
Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.

‎08-11-2011 02:14 AM

Those two papers do not make an absolute case for avoiding statins or allowing higher LDL but they are certainly sufficient to make you think about the present push for very low LDL. In fact, the paper on cancer shows a slightly reduced risk for those using statins. However, it still shows the same V-shaped curve indicating that regardless of statins there is a Goldilocks point: not too little, not too much, but just right for each individual.

That V-shaped curve is roughly 110 to 150 mg/dL (2.8 - 3.8 mmol/L) for cancer and something over 100 mg/dL (2.6 mmol/L) for Parkinsons.

Taken together those papers show me that the doctors blindly accepting the Statin-manufacturers' funded research recommendations to push all patients under 100mg/dL (2.6mmol/L) is questionable at best and that their push to use statins to get diabetics under 70 mg/dL (1.8 mg/dL) is, in my lay opinion, dangerous nonsense.

Too often the doctors forget that cholesterol, in its various forms and components, is a basic building block for the body. Goldilocks was right. We need not too little, not too much, but just right, for us.

PS. Even if the doctors are right about LDL and heart disease (I do not believe they are) then we seem to have three Devil's terrible choices for departure from the planet here: heart attack, Parkinsons or the Big C. If those were my only choices, I know which I would pick.
Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)

‎08-11-2011 09:32 AM

It is not so simple as choosing between cancer, parkinson's and heart disease.

Quite apart from how many times these studies have been repeated, the relative quantitative effect of  lowering or raising LDL cholesteol on each of these has to be studied as well.

Making up some numbers to use as an example, if out of 1000 diabetic patients using statins to reduce LDL cholesterol below 70, some 100 fewer have heart attacks, while 10 more have cancer and 5 more have Parkinson's, well then the trade off is pretty one-sided, except perhaps for someone already in great danger of C or P.   As people with diabetes of course, the thing we are most in danger of is heart disease.

I'm not saying those are the right numbers, but if we are weighing relative risks and rewards, that is the relevant kind of numerical analysis that should be considered.
Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

‎08-12-2011 10:21 PM

Alan, I read the article that you quoted by Huang and collaborators. That article did conclude that Parkinson’s Disease patients had lower Low Density Lipids (LDL). (Huang X, Chen H, Miller WC, et al. Lower low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels are associated with Parkinson’s disease. Mov Disord. 2007;22:377-381.) A later analysis of that same data showed that patients who had taken statins were less likely to develop Parkinson’s Disease. This finding is similar to other studies that have linked statin use to decreased risk of Alzheimer’s disease. (http://www.neura.net/images/pdf/Neura_V7I2_Statins.pdf)

In other words, taking a statin reduces the risk of developing Parkinson’s and Altzeimer’s even though it reduces LDL.

Leland

‎08-13-2011 07:52 AM

A fair point. I'll re-read to see if I come up with the same conclusions.  And there's still the big C.

Part of my logic is to do with why the statins may help in this case. If, as I suspect, it is to do with inflammation reduction and not LDL reduction, then there may be specific uses where statins are appropriate. But there is no case, in my opinion, for the present blanket recommendations to lower LDL to unhealthy levels using chemistry.
Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
